title: 114_hr840
content: The Act may be cited as the "STEM Gateways Act". According to a 2013 Census Bureau study, women are underrepresented in engineering and computing occupations within STEM. The number of engineering degrees awarded to African-American women has declined since the late 1990s. Half of all STEM jobs do not require a 4-year college degree and pay an average of $53,000 per year. STEM jobs pay $53,000 per year on average and offer opportunities for workers with certificates or associate degrees. Only 1/5 of the Federal Government's $4.3 billion annual spending on STEM education supports training below the baccalaureate level. Underrepresented minorities make up only 3 out of 10 professionals in STEM fields. STEM workers earn more than non-STEM counterparts. "Afterschool programs have higher participation rates among African-American, Hispanic, and Native American children compared to the national average. Girls participate equally to boys. This presents an opportunity to engage underrepresented populations in STEM fields and careers." The grant program is authorized. The Secretary will award grants to eligible entities on a competitive basis to carry out programs in STEM fields for women, underrepresented minorities, and individuals from all economic backgrounds at elementary and secondary school levels. The goals include encouraging interest, providing hands-on learning opportunities, and supporting classroom success in STEM disciplines. The Secretary will award grants to eligible entities for STEM programs at elementary and secondary school levels. Grants will support career preparation and education opportunities in STEM fields. Grants are limited to a 5-year period and require an application with specific information. The grant funds will be used for STEM programs at elementary schools to support the success of women, girls, underrepresented minorities, and individuals from all economic backgrounds. The grant funds will support STEM education by recruiting women, girls, underrepresented minorities, and individuals from economically disadvantaged areas. It will also support educators and encourage partnerships. The grant funds will support STEM education by recruiting women, girls, underrepresented minorities, and individuals from economically disadvantaged areas. It will also encourage partnerships between in-school and out-of-school educators, identify public and private partners for support, and plan for financial sustainability beyond the grant period. The eligible entity will implement programs at the secondary school level to achieve STEM education goals, supporting the success of women, girls, underrepresented minorities, and individuals from economically disadvantaged areas. STEM education and workforce training aim to prepare individuals, including women, girls, underrepresented minorities, and those from economically disadvantaged backgrounds, for employment opportunities in STEM fields by recruiting and supporting participants and educators in the programs. STEM education and workforce training focus on preparing individuals for STEM employment opportunities by recruiting and supporting participants and educators in programs. This includes identifying public and private partners, collaborating with higher education institutions and informal science education providers, and planning for financial sustainability beyond the grant period. The grant funds must be used to carry out programs at elementary or secondary schools to achieve STEM education goals for women, underrepresented minorities, and students from all economic backgrounds. This includes reviewing industry needs and analyzing job openings in STEM fields. Authorized use of funds for STEM education programs may include carrying out activities, providing professional development for teachers and school personnel, and offering tutoring and mentoring programs in STEM fields. Providing tutoring, mentoring, partnerships with higher education, employers, and industry stakeholders, after-school activities, informal learning opportunities, and summer programs to enhance skills and interest in STEM fields. Utilizing educational materials. The eligible entities receiving a grant under this Act must submit an annual report to the Secretary detailing the use of funds and the number of students participating in STEM programs funded by the grant. The grant can be used for educational materials, equipment, internships, and experiential learning opportunities in STEM fields. The Secretary must report to Congress annually on the impact and effectiveness of the grant program, based on reports from entities that received grants for STEM programs. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, definitions for terms such as "educational service agency", "elementary school", "local educational agency", "institution of higher education", "secondary school", "Secretary", "State", "community college", and "economically disadvantaged individual" are provided based on specific sections of existing education acts and regulations. The term "economically distressed area" is defined as a county where 40% or more of residents have an income at or below the poverty level. An "eligible entity" includes local educational agencies, educational service agencies, consortiums of local educational agencies, and nonprofit organizations working with schools. The term "STEM" refers to science, technology, engineering, and mathematics. Partners are organizations with expertise in STEM education and workforce development. Community colleges can collaborate with secondary schools for dual enrollment and credit transfer opportunities. The term "STEM" encompasses science, technology, engineering, mathematics, and related academic subjects like computer science. An "underrepresented minority" is defined as per section 637.4(b) of title 34, Code of Federal Regulations.
